explanation: The claim is not correct. The (void)lfs; line is the common, intentional idiom to mark a parameter as unused (and to suppress compiler warnings) when that parameter is not referenced in some build configurations (here the function’s body does not otherwise use lfs). Although the cast-to-void is a no-op at runtime, MISRA Rule 2.2 is intended to prohibit genuinely superfluous executable operations that have no purpose; using (void)param to document/avoid unused-parameter diagnostics is an accepted, deliberate technique and removal would change the build diagnostics (and could be relevant across different preprocessor configurations). In short: this is a deliberate, benign suppression of an unused-parameter warning (not a genuine dead-code defect), so the reported violation is a false positive.
